mods:mods.mods:abstract: Encloses a communication from a friend, a zealous advocate in the cause of peace. If his premises are correct, the conclusions must be consonant. Admitting the possibility of "just and necessary war" in the Old Testament, should we not give preference to the more perfect law of moral rectitude advanced in the gospel? War and bloodshed are not consistent with religion established by the Son of God which we should promote. Wishes John Jay might see war in its true colors, unbiased by judgments not in accordance with the New Testament. Includes a paragraph from a letter describing an interview of Thomas Clarkson with the Emperor of Russia, in which the Emperor expressed his opinion that "War altogether is inconsistent with the Christian." Enclosed letter to Murray purports that wars commanded under the Jewish dispensation do not justify any other wars. Finds no ordinances authorizing war generally in the Old Testament, but only some particular wars which were expressly commanded, inflicting vengeance on nations which had sinned against Jehovah. The Jews themselves were not authorized to wage war at their own discretion. That war by divine command was consistent with moral law is nothing in favor of the wars of any other nation. Also, moral law itself does not authorize wars of any kind. The whole scope of the Jewish dispensation manifests impropriety in reasoning from their government to that of any other people. Those ordinances which authorized the Jews to wage war were limited in obligation; if we take their wars as examples of such that are just and necessary, on what basis can we object to wars of the same nature today? The two principal arguments for war are directly opposed; if invasion is justifiable, self-defense cannot be so. The reasons for Jewish wars can exist only in an absolute Theocracy.
